story:
Once upon a time, in a lush, green jungle in Indonesia, there lived a little girl named Sari. Sari was not like the other children in her village. She had a special gift – she could talk to animals!

Sari spent her days playing with her animal friends and learning all about their unique abilities and talents. She would spend hours listening to the birds sing, watching the monkeys swing from tree to tree, and feeling the gentle touch of the butterflies as they fluttered by.

One day, Sari heard a loud rumble in the distance. She knew that sound – it was the rumbling of thunder! She looked up at the sky and saw dark clouds rolling in.

"Oh no," she thought, "a storm is coming. I hope all of my animal friends are safe."

Sari ran through the jungle, calling out to her friends to take cover. But as she was running, she heard a faint cry for help. She followed the sound and found a small bird trapped in a thicket of thorns.

"Help! I'm stuck!" the bird cried.

Sari carefully made her way through the thorns and gently freed the bird. "Thank you, Sari," the bird said gratefully. "I was so scared."

"You're welcome," Sari replied with a smile. "But we need to find shelter from this storm. Follow me."

Sari led the bird to a large tree with a hollow at the base. They crawled inside and waited out the storm, listening to the rain pouring down and the thunder rumbling in the distance.

When the storm had passed, Sari and the bird emerged from their hiding place. The jungle was wet and muddy, but the sun was starting to peek through the clouds.

"Thank you for saving me, Sari," the bird said. "I will never forget your kindness."

Sari smiled and watched as the bird flew away. She knew that she had made a true friend. From that day on, Sari continued to use her gift to help all of the animals in the jungle, and they all loved and respected her for it.

As Sari crawled into bed that night, she closed her eyes and thought about all of the amazing adventures she had had that day. She drifted off to sleep with a smile on her face, knowing that she had made a difference in the world.

And so, the story of Sari and her animal friends becomes a bedtime story for you, my dear daughter. I hope that you too will learn to use your gifts to help those around you and make a difference in the world. Goodnight, sweet princess. May your dreams be filled with adventure and wonder.
